snippet.title: The initial coin offering promoted by Boxing champ Floyd Mayweather Jr. raises $33 million
snippet.content:
The initial coin offering promoted by boxing champion Floyd Mayweather Jr. has raised $US33 million.
, a blockchain technology startup, ended its ICO, a blockchain-based fundraising method, after receiving $US33 million worth of , according to a press representative for the firm.
Mayweather took to Instagram last week to promote Stox.com's ICO.
According to Mayweather Jr.'s Instagram post, the boxer thought he was going to make a "s- ton of money" from the capital raise. Here's a tweet of the post:
The ICO started on August 2 and ended today.
When asked about Mayweather Jr.'s role in the ICO, a spokesperson for the company told Business Insider US investors were not able to participate in the ICO.
They declined to comment further.
Initial coin offering participants invest money and receive digital "tokens" in return. Thus far, ICOs have been largely unregulated, with some crowdfunding events raising hundreds of millions of dollars. In total, ICOs have raised over $US1.37 billion, according to Lex Sokolin, a partner at Autonomous NEXT, a fintech analytics firm.
Stock.com offers a market prediction platform that aims to enable users to predict future events in everything from finance to politics.
Even a Mayweather fight.
